Despite the occasionally annoying presentation style, it's a reasonable summary.

Reasonable, but not totally accurate.  As a very happy 500e owner, I can offer the following:
*Range - I'm only getting an average of 3.6 miles/kWh - so ~144 miles - and this is always using Range mode for max regen and driving normally on a mix of road types.
*Driving is fun and the car is both nippy and confident (my other car is a BMW i3, and the 500e actually tracks better).
*Interior - I was/am pleasantly impressed with the build quality and most of the materials quality; there's one of one exceptions, but all-in-all it's very good (again, my benchmark is a BMW).
*Practicality - well, it's a Fiat 500 for goodness sake and nobody should be expecting a Tardis.  Having said that, it's more than capable of taking our large weekly shop or carry-on luggage for two.  Again people, it's a city car..!
*Specs - I have the La Prima model, so top-of-the-range.  The specs are pretty amazing, with very driver assistance gizmo you could wish for.  Honestly, the only thing missing is folding door mirrors; but I guess the car is regarded as narrow enough for this to be a moot point.


I would definitely recommend people considering a city car EV to take one for test drive.

In my channel I reviewed the Fiat 500e as well! I can confirm you have a good point! Your points are valid I agree with you almost everywhere, but there is ONE major flaw: the price. For that price, we all have expectations! I personally would've expected a tardis-like experience if I were to pay beyond 30k Euros for an A-segment car. For 30k one could get a C-segment (like a Golf or Astra) car which is similar to the 500e in terms of city friendliness, but MORE easy to live with!

@@autochampwandelen Well, price - or more accurately, value - is all in the mind of the buyer.  For me, I believe the 500e delivers much for the price I paid, and the sales numbers reflect that this is a common-enough view.  The level of tech, the impressive build quality, and the sense of style all combine to deliver a valuable package.  A car purchase, any car purchase, is a discretionary spend, so value is totally subjective.

@@autochampwandelen One more thing on price.  You mentioned Golf and Astra; neither a pure EV platforms, and so the comparison is moot.  Additionally, many of the legacy manufacturers, when offering an EV version of their compromise vehicle architectures, will spec and price the EV at the highest end of the range; ICE will be available with an entry-level spec/price, but not the EV option.  Fiat, with the 500e, do at least offer all term/spec/price levels, making the EV accessible to a broader customer base.  And that has to be a good thing.

I bought a Fiat 500e Passion (in rose gold) two months ago and it is a belter of a car with bags of power, great build quality and a brilliant driving experience, particularly in one-pedal drive mode. It replaced a Renault Twingo GT which had identical dimensions, so the boot and cabin are large enough for me and it also fits into my garage. Hi Brian, how do you find the battery life to mileage and the charging time?

@@fc4660 Hi F C. Over the winter, I averaged about 3.8 miles per KW/h in mixture of town and (50-60 mph) main road driving, all with a light foot. This has recently risen to 4.25 miles per KW/h during early Spring, so range is now about 160 miles. I have read that the Fiat can be charged at 85 KW on public fast chargers but I have only ever used my home wallbox which is set very low to match my solar PV system's output, so it is currently costing me very little to run. Hope this is of some help.

I've always liked the 500, and this is a good review, but it captures in a nutshell the huge problem we have with EV's right now - price and range. The most basic 500-e is nearly ¬£10k more than the entry petrol version, that's ¬£25k for a very small, basic, low range car, and that climbs to ¬£30k for a higher spec model. THIRTY GRAND! This is why EV's are mostly being bought by the well off at the moment - people who will always have a second ICE car for longer journey's where they're still way more practical. We're still 5 years or more away from sensibly priced EV's with better battery tech.
Buying on a contract and saving the difference between the petrol and ev version on fuel bills makes it cost effective.

@@jonwetherell5214 Possibly with a very small car, but this is the argument everyone makes - buy on contract. At this price though, even with a moderate deposit, you're looking at ¬£3-400 per month for a Fiat 500e, which is crazy (Kia EV6, mid-spec on PCP deal is around ¬£7-800pm). This is just totally impractical for most average buyers, especially with many now struggling just to keep the heating on and put food on the table. With electicity prices soaring it's also going to get more expensive to charge EV's too.

Good reviewüëçüôÇ although I'm not sold on electric vehicles, when we don't have enough charging points at the moment. Hybrid makes more sense.  When most cars take at least a few hours to charge, the city charge points won't make sense.  This is why utility bills are going up. Trying to run before we can walk. Electricity isn't a "greener" energy source.  Powercuts, blackouts will be a regular occurrence

This is a common misconception and the National Grid disagrees with you. Two thirds of UK homeowners have access to a driveway and, therefore, a home charger. They can charge at night making use of a currently under utilised electricity availability from wind power. Add in solar panels and storage from used EV batteries, not to mention vehicle-to-grid (where cars charge when prices are low and sell their cars electricity to the grid when prices are high) and you can see there really is no shortage. It is NOT why utility bills are going up (you really need to do yourself a favour and google why they ARE going up). The charging infrastructure could do with improvement, though, I agree with that.

I just drove one today and was disappointed. The infotainment system is terrible (cluttered menu and counter-intuitive) and having buttons to select the gear is an idea you need to have a very peculiar mind to find useful. The indicator arm was mechanical and often remains in the active position after you complete the turn. The navigation was slow and fiddly. 

Unless you‚Äôre a family of midgets or your passengers are pugs, the backseat is only for show. 

It‚Äôs hard to see where the car ends (both ends). The lane assist was worse than driving with an anxious mother-in-law in the backseat. 

The worst thing was the lack of mechanical door opening. To get out of the car, you press a button so make sure you NEVER run the battery to zero or you will need to break a window to escape.

The positives: Good acceleration and nice dashboard. The size is of course convenient but that‚Äôs common for all small cars. Two USB ports but the old USB2 standard instead of USB-C which is the new standard and a proper space for your phone. Good size cup holders and the glove compartment was decent for the car size. The seats were comfortably firm. 

All in all I think this is a car that will appeal much more to women than to men. They may find its quirks more charming than utilitarian men.
I would personally go for a used Renault Zoe, cheaper, bit more practical in terms of storage and still compact and nimble.

I have always liked the 500, I was lucky enough to own an early proper 500 (1968 model with the 499cc 2 cylinder petrol engine), it still has an appealing look even now though I don't think much of the headlight design, the lower range battery would be no good for me as I do a 74 mile round trip daily commute which is mostly motorway miles, in this area, the infrastructure just isn't good enough, having done some research, at present it's still cheaper to run my 2011 Smart diesel as I am unable to have a home chargepoint, I would have to have another vehicle to complete my working weeks journeys as I would only be able to charge up on my days off due to the only chargepoints being in a car park which closes at night, I work long unsociable hours and wouldn't be able to get to the car park during opening hours very often.

At present I am going to have to stick with my little Smart diesel until battery range on vehicles improves and prices become more affordable, admittedly battery ranges are improving, in so many reviews, it's assumed that drivers want range for doing longer journeys, in many cases this is true, but it's also needed for those of us who are unable to have a home chargepoint and where the infrastructure is also very poor, just as a side point, I have written to my local councils and MP on many occasions but have never received a response.

@@fortheloveofnoise9298I have a 2013 FIAT 500 Abarth as well an with almost 200,000/miles, it‚Äôs not going anywhere as well. It‚Äôs been across the US and I have had it since it was brand new. Maintaining it has never broke the bank and there hasn‚Äôt been any mechanical issues/failures.
@@LemironStarlingwhat maintenance did you do around 100k? Mines almost at 100k

@@mateorosas1272 I‚Äôm happy you asked, if you have a 500 Tubro(500T), Abarth or a 500 after 2019 with the Tubro as the only engine. You must change the spark plugs at 30K intervals. If not it will make the ignition coils fail eventually and cause a miss fire. 

Have the engine coolant and brake fluid flush. I also recommend having your serpentine belt checked and it might need to be replaced. 

Just recently I have found out the AOS(Air Oil Separator) should be cleaned and gasket replaced along with the PCV valve at 40K. One might not have any problems if pushed but if not taken care of can make one think they have a bad engine with light white smoke at a stop or idle. It literally a $35 fix/maintenance in parts to make sure you 500 keeps running great.

Along with your oil changes, battery replacements and engine air filter changes this should help get you to 200K. I happy to answer any other questions.

as an owner of a 2013 Abarth 500 (5spd) and a 2015 Abarth 500 ( 6spd auto). Neither were a problem ( at all).... I am intrigued by this new (forthcoming) Abarth 500 EV provided it offers improvements over the prior ICE cars....For example - Is it quicker?, More torque?, IRS ? improved interior? Front LSD ? and is it affordable?

We‚Äôre replacing our 2014 Abarth 500C Esseesse (160bhp) with a top-spec new FIAT 500e (equivalent of La Prima). Less power and torque (similar to a 1.4 non-turbo 500 Lounge). It‚Äôs going to be about two seconds slower 0-60, top speed some 30mph lower (we never use top speed anyway), but it‚Äôs a whole lot smoother and easier to drive without that awful gearbox. No need for a limited slip diff as it doesn‚Äôt have that surge of turbo power/can‚Äôt spin the wheels!

Driving position is more comfortable (seats are better), it‚Äôs quieter, and ride is smoother with the 400kg extra weight.

Running costs will be a quarter or less - our electricity is cheaper than in Europe or the UK (in NZ we pay the equivalent of 6p/kWh to charge at night when hydro power is plentiful). Our petrol is as expensive as yours.

FIAT have old-technology batteries and motors compared to Tesla, so FIAT‚Äôs EV is relatively slow and not as efficient. My Model 3 Performance has 480bhp vs. the 113bhp of the 500e, yet the efficiency of the larger and heavier Tesla is the same as the 500e. And you can buy a used Model 3 Performance (dual motor AWD) for the same money as a new 500e. Model 3 weighs no more than a similarly-sized petrol BMW 3-series AWD. That‚Äôs probably why it‚Äôs such a great car.

Multilink IRS in the Tesla compared to torsion beam in the 500e means there‚Äôs not really any comparison in how the cars feel - 500e will have that bouncy twitchy handling we know from the Abarth :) Drum rear brakes in the 500e. The Abarth 500e gets rear discs, a bit more power (150bhp) - but costs even more - is it worth it? In the old Abarth 500, compared to the Lounge we had, the difference in suspension tuning was obvious; I‚Äôm not so sure that will be the case with the extra weight of the 500e platform.

The FIAT 500e is also the same price as a brand-new basic Model 3 which still has more than twice the power and 33% more range, so it‚Äôs a no-brainer to pick the Tesla, better fast-charging options too. Reports of trim and build quality concerns are greatly exaggerated‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt think FIAT will sell many 500e here. Basically, it‚Äôs like buying an early Nissan Leaf, but about five times the price and much more exclusive :)

Quentin, 

where did you get the idea that evs are better for the environment than ICEs? Not from Robert Llewelyn, by any chance, because he is totally deluded.
While we have, in the U.K., some renewable generation they do not go to charging electric cars (or heat pumps for that matter). essentially electric cars are powered by gas. It would be better to cut out the middle man and go for propane to power ic engines which would be far more efficient. (There are a large amount of losses between generation and consumer). 
The reason is how our grid works. Nuclear and renewables run at maximum available at all times so cannot respond to the extra load evs put on the grid, this is met by gas which can respond and provide the extra power. The government put the horse before the cart, they should have decarbonised the grid first but that can only be done by nuclear, renewables haven't a hope, they are practically and technically unsuited for large scale grid supply.
Don't take my word for it, an inteligent assessment of this site shows real time grid performance:- https://www.gridwatch.templar.co.uk/.
Note particularly the red and blue in the second column of graphs, red being gas and blue being wind and bear in mind that wind is always at maximum, gas is variable and can rise to meet extra demand.

Yep. Charge network is key. Ive run a Tesla through work for a few years, and its actually ok, because the network is good and reliable, and doesn't need cards/logins/dongles etc. Its also high output and the software in the car plans the routes of long journeys for you pretty well to keep charging stops brief. The chargers also discourage people from sitting on them which helps with availability. Im sad they didn't keep the 'range extender' type cars going (we have an i3 as the run around) - yes, its a 'hybrid', but its the 'other  way round', ie a serial hybrid,  and as a result, you don't end up using petrol at all often as most journeys are less than 100 miles in reality. Plus, on a long run you can just use fuel for the faster bits, its easy to refill and will run all day if needed. You always have 'full power' as the drive is purely electric (unless you really run the battery low). The weight penalty makes only a very  little difference to economy, and the petrol engine can be quite basic as it just needs to generate electricity. But mainly, you can avoid using public chargers!

my issue with electric cars isn't the "purity", it's purely environmental. the battery has a lifespan of 100,000 miles tops before needing replacement. the lithium, cobalt and nickel used in the batteries is mined in horrific working conditions, often using child slave labour at gunpoint. the environmental impact of this is huge. while ev lithium ion batteries are supposedly 95% recycleable, less than 5% of ev batteries are actually recycled. the effects of lithium, cobalt, nickel etc when returning to the earth are slightly less horrific than the child slave labour, but still, really bad.

nickel mining alone is eating away at the rainforest, and if the plans to make roads fully electric in the nearish future suceed, it will accelerate this process 10 fold (actually, a lot more than tenfold, but you get the point). they are not sustainable or a long term solution, and rely on third world countries with abhorent working conditions for production. spending 5-10k for a replacement battery, after anywhere between 25-100k miles is financially and enviromentally stupid, considering how many dirty diesels have done 250,000+ miles with basic maintenence. hell most service diesels see 400k - 1,000,000+ with regular maintenence. 

ALSO not to mention that our electricity grid is barely holding up as is and is not nearly renewable enough. it is simply not feasible for mass ownership as of now.

If you want to minimize pollution of cars, which itself is a tiny figure of global pollution (private jets cause more pollution than all of fucking denmark combined for example and thats still a small drop in the ocean), figure out how to lower diesel tailpipe emissions, as the compression ratio's are high enough to run on non fossil fuels.

if you want to do your bit through what you drive - buy a car, any car, new, old, diesel petrol etc and look after it. the consumer throwaway culture is maddening to me personally. petition for the government to auction off the cars held under the 2008 scrappage scheme (even just for parts) which ruined the 2nd hand car market, effecting the poorest the most and generally being a senseless waste of perfectly adequate equipment.

tl;dr - if you want to drive an ev because you enjoy it, no worries, just don't make/be fooled by the pretenses that it has any positive effect whatsoever on the planet.

thanks for coming to my ted talk.

Didn't think lithium mining was anywhere near rainforest. Isn't Argentina one of the main producers? Also, 100,000 is definitely not the limit for battery life. Plenty of EVs have clocked up way more miles on their original battery.

@@HubNut rainforests in south america / asia are rife with minerals like that. i think i mistyped in the original - lithium mining is mostly south american whereas nickel and cobalt is more asian/african, however the working conditions are simmilarly poor in all places. ethanol production is also a huge contributor to deforestation (mostly south america, though ethanol fields are quickly eating up north american farmland). 

i'm honestly glad to hear the battery life is better than I had heard; i'm not so much an ev connoseiur so such news is reassuring - i was just using figures i'd found from online sources over the years.

imo its far more of a political issue all around (environment, gov sanctions on petrol/diesel, muh freedoms etc) than a fundamental issue with ev's - they definitely have their pro's and i think a lot of people who live in a city would probably be better off with a small ev (or even a quadrocycle or gwiz or something) for their shop runs instead of a massive crossover.

as a side note - love the content, great watch as always. keen for what the new year will bring!

That Fiat computerised (rear) wiper interval really is a struggle. I have a 2016 Fiat Doblo... It doesn't have auto-wipers, the rear wiper just wipes once every two sweeps of the front wipers. However, if you don't have the front wipers on, it doesn't pick the slowest speed, it wipes as if it was syncing with the front wipers on low continuous speed, which is way too fast for just wiping spray. The interval for both the front and rear wipers is also non-adjustable but speed-dependant, so at higher speeds there's very little difference between interval and low speed while at slower speeds the interval is sometimes too slow but it doesn't rain enough to select low speed continuous.
My previous car (2001 Volvo V70) had adjustable interval (from very very slow to alsmost continuous) on the front wipers and two stages of rear wiper (a nice medium-slow interval and continuous), I liked that a lot better.
Ow, and to top it all off, my Doblo has the same wiper stalk situation as a Multipla: you have to twist the end for the front wipers and a ring for the rear wiper, the stalk itself just moves up for one front wipe, to the dash for rear wash, to the driver for front wash.

One thing I don't understand....if there is a manual door release override....why have the electronic release at all? Then you're just wasting weight on having TWO door opening mechanisms? Why not ONLY have the manual release and save the extra weight and complexity...?
True, but it does make it the same as a Renault Alpine or TVR. ;-)

@@HubNut That it does, yes! Though I think it's just as pointless on those cars as well. If you have a mechanical release that's known to be very reliable, generally, and does the exact same function, why would anyone need to add electronic releases in the first place? :(

I find a lot of things like that with modern cars... I'm not against modern cars, but there's this trend to add things that aren't really necessary in my eyes. Backup cameras, for example....

I understand how they're useful on large commercial vehicles like trucks or vans, or big SUVs... But here in North America, they've been mandated on every vehicle. Why does something like a small  crossover or hatchback need a backup camera? It's not large, so should be fairly easy to park using the rear view mirror or side mirrors... In places like here in Canada, where poor winter weather means that cameras are just going to get covered with slush and snow and ice as you're driving, or salt spray that's kicked up from behind the car on wet Winter roads... The camera lens is going to get all dirty and blurry and useless anyway, but a plain old rear view mirror inside that has done its job perfectly acceptably for decades is not :(

Let alone the repair cost... If your rear view mirror breaks, you just glue another one to your windshield. If you're backup camera breaks, it's likely hundreds and hundreds of dollars to repair (at least here in Canada).

LED headlight assemblies are another example. I'm not against LEDs as they provide superior light, put modern cars have the LEDs embedded in the assembly, meaning if one of the LEDs Burns out, you have to spend potentially hundreds or even thousands on expensive cars to replace the entire assembly for one burnt out LED. Why not design the housings to have replaceable LED bulbs that use the same standard sockets and contacts that we've had for decades? Rather than spending thousands to replace the entire assembly, you could just swap the bulb out as we've done, but still have the benefit of LEDs?

Sorry for the mini rant, haha! Just some observations I've had :)

Great video, excellent review of 'the future'. I am also impressed how you've managed to spawn your own police force of contributors who launch pre-emptive strikes against anyone who is going to say anything negative about EVs. Just to annoy (goad?) that crew I'll say this, in the spirit of summing up what I think: EVs are great as a concept and in practice for many motorists. They are likely to be the way to get about independently in the future. In reality, it's another step in the direction of cars becoming sterile containers. Charging is not great on the public network, and is now the equivalent of ¬£1.30 a litre on my local council network. So they are not going to be marketed as cheap to either buy, or even to run. The idea of considering how to dress while in the car because you don't want to put the heating on is frankly bonkers. I regard wearing a coat and thick socks while driving as a bit odd. If they charged much more quickly (10 mins from min to max), and there were a lot more charge points, I don't think there would be anywhere near as much negativity. It's the future, and will be the way to get about, but an EV is not something we will be likely to take out for a run to soak up the atmosphere. I think that's what upsets some, it's the end of motoring as a fun thing with character.
Thing is, I'll never stop loving my character cars but I love the experience of driving electric.

@@royblackburn1163 You make some good points but also get some thing wrong. Your reasons for not going for an electric car yet are all valid. That you have to charge them with dirty electricity is completely false. I don't! I'm on a clean tariff and have solar. Nuclear power, I grudgingly admit that we probably need it, like we need to mine for minerals to make our cars, and like we need to devote resources to grow  ourselves food. Let's look at each case and try and improve how we do things rather than throw in the towel and keep polluting ourselves to oblivion.

@@royblackburn1163 I'm not sure how renewables can be thought unreliable, the sun seems to come up every day and the wind is always blowing somewhere. I think I know what you mean though, you can't produce solar during the night and occasionally the wind might drop, even in the North Sea. This is where storage will come in. We have a plan, it isn't all in place yet but it can and will work, I'm confident of it. This problem that Putin is causing is a temporary spanner in the works. I can see some knee jerk reactions happening (such as renewed calls for fracking) but wish the powers that be could understand that if they spent the same money on renewables and the systems to make them work, we could not only get these problems solved more quickly than any other method could, but it would also be sustainable. @@royblackburn1163 I think your first point is answered (or will be) by storage. You make a good point but I believe the answer is there. We are totally in agreement on nuclear and fracking it seems. I reckon you're doing your bit with the car and bike. I'm an 'ex-but itching to be again' biker and so I'm bound to ask what bike you have. I would love a Zero or something similar but alas, circumstances make it out of the question for the moment. Your 'Landy' sounds awesome. You should not feel (and it seems you don't) guilt for keeping a classic. I would argue against it being as 'green' as an EV, simply because you still have to burn fossil fuel to go anywhere, but lovely old cars like this have a place. As long as mass transport gets cleaner, I hope we can justify keeping and running classics. Of course, a Mitsubishi Evo (just as an extreme example to make a point) is a future classic! Perhaps biofuels can make these oldies even more guilt free. I have heard that companies (Porsche for one) are working on synthetic fuels, so there may be other options. I am optimistic for the future, I can see a day when we can squander as much energy as we can think of ways of doing so and it will be sustainable. This will give us the best of all worlds. All the best, Tim

The United States need a small car that is an EV for upper lower income and for lower middle income earners and for students, young families and 55+ seniors, who really aren't looking for 200+ mile range and costing 40K and up. That said Fiat has designed this great model but as in the U.S.'s past can't just sit back and wait for its sales to drop off before making design or feature changes. Just had a loner one when my Alfa was at service. What a great little car! 
The tech is quite good, I didn‚Äôt expect that honestly. The screen feels little weird is it‚Äôs not pointing towards toe driver. The powertrain feels strong and makes the car move with quite some punch around town. It makes interesting EV noises which I like a lot and add the to driving experience in my opinion. 
The normal driving mode is well calibrated and feels like a nice automatic car without applying a lot of regen braking. In the other two ¬´¬†range friendly¬†¬ª modes the regen braking is pretty aggressive and need some getting used to.
The ride quality isn‚Äôt the best ok earth but I was expecting way worse form a SWB ¬´¬†affordable¬†¬ª car. It‚Äôs not soft but the suspension did absorb bumps and road imperfections pretty nicely.

The build quality is somewhat inconsistent around the car. Some party feel well made and high quality and others seem to have been but together by a blind person in the dark‚Ä¶ for example the stitching is so bad that you don‚Äôt have to look at is the figure that out, it felt cheap. Why is it "strange" that this piece of rubbish was only sold in California and Oregon? Answer (plain as the nose on your face) is that it is a COMPLIANCE CAR. Fiat is resisting going into EV like a virgin into a Adult Toys shop. Fiat has no desire to sell these and makes them ONLY because the penalty for not doing so is onerous.
This car is redundant even before you buy it. Its only redeeming factor is that it's EV and for everyone sold (won't be that many) an ICE car is left unsold.

@@neutronalchemist3241 You have been drawn in by the hype. Don't for one minute think that Fiat is making EV's because they WANT to make EV's. They (like all legacy automakers) would FAR, FAR prefer to NOT make Ev's at all - ever.
These companies have been dragged kicking and screaming and crying howls of protest into the EV arena, because of three main reasons:
1. Civilised countries are going to BAN the sale of new ICE vehicles within the next 10 years,
2. ICE cars are increasingly penalised with emissions fines, which is starting to really hurt them.
3. The public is finding EV's more economically attractive (total cost of ownership, not sticker price) and in addition, are seeing cars like Tesla as VERY desirable. (Tesla was the ONLY car maker to make good profist during the covid pandemic. EVERY OTHER CAR MAKER suffered big losses.
Fiat is making this piece of rubbish ONLY BECAUSE THEY HAVE NO CHOICE... not becuase they want to.

@@brunosmith6925 Every company would prefer to do what it has always done, but the sales of electric cars in Europe rised 50% EVERY YEAR in the last 5 years.The actual situation is that, if you are a car maker and wants to remain relevant, you have to manufacture electric vehicles, so what FIAT does? Manufacture electric vehicles. 
That's not building "compliance car". It's building what the market is asking for, that's what manufacturers exist for.

The previous 500e was a compliance car, made to be sold only in California, because California mandated any manufacture must sell an EV if they want continue to sell their ICE cars. And California being one of the largest car markets in the world, FCA really had no choice.
The CitiGo iV stopped at only 400 imported into the UK, you can order a SEAT Mii Electric or VW e-Up!

It's not much of a jump up to a Honda, which means that you don't need to deal with the FCA after sales "service". But then it's not that much of a jump up from the Honda to a Tesla, which gets you that charging network, plus 400 km range, which means it's a complete petrol replacement, not a "second" car. If you're OK with the size of the Tesla.

EVERY review of an EV talks about range -- a lot. I'm so tired of even hearing about it. "I keep wanting a Honda e," despite the range. Then you're a fool if you don't own one, mate! You know what people don't talk about very much? The actual range of ICE cars. I mean: in a review of a new ICE car, some mention of the range for that particular car. It's very rare. You know why? BECAUSE RANGE DOESN'T REALLY MATTER SO MUCH. This Clean Technica article from 2016 said the median range for ICE was 412 miles. 50% of ICE vehicles in 2016 got less than 412 miles on a tank. Remember back in 2016, when everyone was complaining about ICE range? Me neither! Why did I link an article from way back in 2016? Because I couldn't find a more recent article on the subject of ICE range. I just know that some ICE muscle cars, you know, the ones competing for market share with Model 3's and Taycans and Lucid Air's, have ranges under 200 miles! Let's range-shame THEM! Range anxiety? To me, it's range insanity. Wake up and smell the cheap abundant electricity everywhere. https://cleantechnica.com/2016/08/26/electric-vehicle-ranges-exceed-gasoline-powered-vehicles-chart/

I had one of the original 500es! Glad you mentioned that one. It was my first-ever EV, I leased one here in San Diego from 2014 to 2017 for my 60-mile round-trip commute.

Another nice Vlog with great camera work, imagery, and sound/musicüëç! Love your honest reviews pointing out all the good and bad, and even what other cars are better choices, have better options, and prices! Love the looks of the 500e and the slightly larger dimensions and wheels (actually not a bad look for you as well with your outfit). Cool little touch with the way they integrated the "e" inside the 0 of the 500. Nice interior, the center display didn't look like some slapped on iPad like some other vehicles, and the built in wireless phone chargers are nice. Sounded like it had a really nice quite interior, good soundproofing, and the motor didn't sound whiny or droning inside the cab while you were talking or as it was driving by on the exterior shots. Only 4 things I could pick out that i didn't like were, 1: The musical start/stop is a cute touch that could be fun to show off, but I imagine after hearing it dozens and dozens of times it could get annoying. 2: I wish the roof would tuck down further for better rear visibility. 3: Don't like the location of the switches in the center console because they seem like they could be accidentally hit easily. 4: Really don't like the electric door releases. If you have an electrical problem, how do you open the door? Break a window to get out? I prefer a hard connection with a normal cable latch, because even if the handle or cable broke both doors wouldn't be broken at the same time, the way electrically operated doors could be, and you could climb across to use the other door. When every single thing is electrically operated on an electric car it starts to seem gimmicky and unnecessary, and just an extra power drain on the battery (even if it's just a tiny fraction of power that it uses). Ditch power door handles, get rid of touch screen digital controls for the radio (leave the connections on the steering wheel for safety, not having to move your hands and eyes), leave the climate controls as dials and switches or levers, and no power operated steering column adjustments that add heavy motors. That all being said it's still a really nice car that I would buy....but probably look for someone to modify the doors to some standard Fiat door handles!

Great review. I love the story aspect, there's enough detail for us geeks, and it gives a good  impression of what the car is capable of.
I don't really understand what has happened to small EVs over the last few years though. The new ones (MINI, Honda, FIAT, even the Peugeot/Vauxhall) offer numbers similar to a Zoe from 3 years ago (OK, with a little faster charging), but for significantly more money. They seem to be trying to justify that with styling and tech, but it feels like it's back to front - make a really good platform (e-Panda?) and then put the premium styled/featured car at the top of the range for those who care about that sort of thing. The Zoe is a 10 year old design, and thanks to the battery and tech upgrades (and CCS), it's still the best everyday car.

I'm kind of astonished what a fantastic job they've done on this; especially the powertrain and the pricing. A properly usable EV for ¬£20k (with more range than the ¬£30k Leaf of 5 years ago)? And nearly 200 miles with 85kW charging for ¬£23.5k?? That's at the low end of Golf pricing, and gives some minigun-level ammunition against the gripe that EVs are too expensive.

Particularly surprising that this is coming from Fiat. They don't have much pedigree with EVs; if I remember rightly the original 500e compliance car had the powertrain design and engineering done by a third party. It's also the company formerly headed by famously anti-EV Sergio Marchionne, who once requested that customers not buy the original 500e. The new car is a genuine milestone, and it's come from a really surprising place.

I‚Äôve ran a Zoe for 18 months at a fraction of the cost of buying a second hand ICE‚Äôd car. I‚Äôve done all the things you aren‚Äôt supposed to be able to do, commuting 56 miles a day. Regular trips from Torquay to Heathrow, Luton and Stanstead airports. Usually covered between 1,500 and 1,800 miles a month. I can‚Äôt charge at home or at work. Far quieter and smoother than it should be for its size. And unlike your average small hatch, you can‚Äôt be bullied in traffic as you are with a small ICE hatch. This Fiat is top of my list. And liking the 11kW AC, very useful. Oh I know have an electric van and electric motorbike. I‚Äôm not wealthy, I just take more notice of the advantages of EVs than most. I‚Äôm a MV tech so can keep old ICE stuff on the road cheaper than most, but the running costs of EVs and very low maintenance is unbeatable. The infrastructure needs to be better but it is getting better very quickly now.

I don't get the whole interest in electric cars, it's not the future, it's not sustainable from start to end and it's not green.
I get it for small one off specials but mass production with the issue of supply in the metals required for the batteries.... It doesn't work.
Why are we supporting the Chinese as this is where the the batteries are produced? Why aren't we supporting hydrogen fuel cell technology which is where the UK come in? Infinitely more sustainable and much more green.... In essence we are supporting the wrong technology as a race.
Totally agree. Especially as the new Toyota mirai shows it can be done properly.

I'm all for a full hydrogen based infrastructure. We have more tidal, wind and hydro potential than most nations and we aren't exactly lacking in water of any kind. We have plenty of resources available to be fully energy independent.

You do realize that fuel cells have even more exotic and expensive materials than batteries and HFCEVs still have batteries anyway? And that the losses just never work out. Why throw away half of the energy you produce for an expensive, difficult storage medium? How is that "green"?

@@patreekotime4578 I do realise they have exotic materials however, they are in far more plentiful supply than those used in batteries. There are presently only 3 countries able to mine the metals for batteries and if a country the size of Wales decided tomorrow that only battery cars were to be used (3 million people) one of those countries producing these metals would dry up completely.
The other aspect from an environmental perspective is where do these batteries go at end of life?
In the UK Ineos is already producing 350 thousand tonnes of hydrogen a year and have signed a deal with Kia to get things moving.
We then come on to charging electric cars, how can people in terrace houses charge them, do we leave cables running over pavements (sidewalks) for people to trip over?
We already have a ready made infrastructure for dispensing hydrogen, they are called petrol stations (gas stations).
Safety is no less than that of battery cars, the car Richard Hammond crashed (Rimac) took three days to extinguish the fire due to all the cells combusting in a chain reaction.
Then we come into the shipping of the metals from various countries to China..... Heavy fuel oil, at least in Europe we have MGO (Marine Gas Oil) which a more highly refined fuel emitting less fumes. China are not yet interested in lowering emissions.
Oh and by the way, the UK national grid (electricity) is already running at 95% capacity.
The only reason this is all going ahead is due to government, the same was true of diesel engines and look where that got us, solved the o zone but gave more people is cities breathing problems.... Now they are taxing us out of diesel into another white elephant.

Regenerative braking should primarily be done when applying the brake pedal, not automatically with one pedal driving. I know EV buyers love one pedal driving, but aggressive one pedal driving can be dangerous, particularly in the city. You can't maintain speed and cover the brake pedal at the same time, reducing your reaction time. This is one of the reasons Tesla has such extremely high accident rates.
In driving school, you are taught when and where to cover the brake pedal, like around pedestrians or when a driver is sitting in a car that is parallel parked.

I disagree, having blended braking can make the brake pedal very unpredictable in a lot of cars (like in the Maverick Hybrid where it feels like you're slamming on the brakes below ~7mph and it's extremely hard to stop smoothly), I prefer having the brake pedal just connected hydraulically, and leave the gas pedal lift-off for regen... gives you more braking confidence when you need it. If you make the regen strong enough, it should be able to bring the vehicle to a stop quickly and smoothly, especially once you get used to it.

@@Black-Villain That is a separate issue that isn't found in all cars with regenerative braking. 

Regardless, one pedal driving shouldn't replace covering your brake pedal.  Regenerative braking is not meant for emergency stops. It shouldn't matter how smooth it is or isn't, an emergency stop is an emergency stop. The faster you stop, the better.

@@allentechpt9026 Exactly, regen doesn't replace emergency stops, that's what your brake pedal is for. If you have your foot off of the gas pedal while regen-ing anyway, there's no reason you can't cover the brake pedal for an emergency stop. I did this the few times back when I had my i3 and was driving downtown in urban areas
tell me you don't know what you are talking about, without tell me you don't know what you are talking about.

@@Black-Villain Yes, there is a reason. If regen is so strong, you are going to keep your foot on the accelerator to maintain speed. This means you cannot cover the brake and maintain speed. This is not a problem in cars without regen.
@@stgeorgee I'm not wrong about anything.  You cannot maintain speed with regenerative brake. Your comment doesn't refute that.
@@kendrick5909 You can also fail a driving exam by use of regenerative brake.
Due the lack of proper driver training, many people don't even comprehend the purpose of covering the brake.
@@geragosian805 That's right, there are examples of people falling driver's tests because they didn't cover their brake pedals.

@@allentechpt9026 I feel like you haven't driven many EV's... or at least not for a long period of time. There's no reason to maintain speed in an EV. You see your intersection/stop sign/whatever coming up, you know how long it takes the car to naturally stop, you let off of the gas. You can feel free to cover the brake pedal from that point if you're in an area with pedestrians

This also can apply to engine and exhaust brakes on diesels. On our trucks' diesels, the exhaust brakes only work at certain RPM. At low speeds and low RPM, the exhaust brake completely shuts off. Those who complain about poor blending brakes, well, that to your delivery driver. It's about the most poorly blended braking you can imagine. 

Still, it's for safety because it's better than slower reaction time. Covering the brake is just basic, basic safety training.

@@Black-Villain Part of my job is driving EVs or cars with regenerative braking. I also work with insurance companies that are studying this issue. Regenerative braking has become a massive safety issue.

In any way, your ad hominem doesn't refute a thing I've said, so everything I said still stands.

This is what Driver's Ed says.

"The cover braking technique involves taking your right foot off the accelerator and holding it over the brake pedal. If you have to stop quickly, your foot is already above the brake pedal and is in the perfect position to press the brake. This method will improve your reaction time. So, whenever you identify a hazard, cover the brake to prepare for sudden stops or slowing. When covering the brake, be careful not to rest your foot on the brake pedal (also known as riding the brake). Riding the brake is not recommended; it will only confuse other drivers and add unnecessary wear to the brakes."

@@allentechpt9026you know you can move your foot right? I‚Äôve been driving EV‚Äôs for over seven years and I have never had a problem putting my foot on the brake when I needed to stop quickly. The overwhelming majority of the time you are used to how the one pedal deceleration works and take your foot off the accelerator and let the thing slow down behind the car in front.

‚Äã@@allentechpt9026 imagine this situation.

You're driving along at 60mph and all of a sudden, traffic stops in front of you with your foot on the accelerator. 

The moment you lift off to apply the hydraulic brakes, the regen is already workibg at max power to slow down before you're even applying the hydraulic brakes. 

If we are using regen on the brake pedal, you're driving along and you life off to apply the brakes, you get nothing until the brake is fully applyed passed the point of regen. 

Having more response is always safer and having the car slow down from lifting your foot up before even applying the brake is going to slow you down faster than if one pedal driving was not enabled.

‚Äã@@allentechpt9026 i have a feeling its due to a false sense of safety and the kind of people that buy ev's are generally those that have their car do the work for them. I mean look at all those idiots in tesla's falling asleep at the wheel with autopilot. 

When those people drive ice cars, they usually have lower tech and must therefore pay attention. But once they're put into a high tech ekectric car that does all the paying attention for them, they slack off and let the car do the work. 

That's my thinking as to why ev's end up in more accidents. Its not the cars, but the people who choose to buy cars with a high level of technology that lets them be lazy.

‚Äã@@kenmcclow8963hes talking about emergency braking.

Say you're driving through town coasting, you should have your foot above the brake pedal ready to stop when needed in an emergency. 

As someone who also drives ev's, i still don't see this as an issue because anything other than something apearing right in front of you out of nowhere, would make the difference and the moment you fully lift off, its already applying max regen belts you apply friction brakes. 

So it really doesn't seem like that big of a deal. The problem is the drivers drivibg ev's, not ev's themselves. My dad is a good driver but for some reason once he gets into his tesla with all its cameras and sensors, he basically completely relys on the car to do the work for him. I will never be like this and only use the tech if its better than doing it myself, like backibg up using the camera because theres significantly less visibility out the back than in the camera on our car. But ill still use mirrors and such and base things off visual cues instead of what the car tells tells me.

@@user-rm7kb3il6x The level of assistance from regen braking is minimal. You also don't need one pedal driving or even regenerative brakes for that to work. Many non-regen European cars have had brake assist for years.

@@user-rm7kb3il6x I think driving around with a foot hovering in the air above the pedals is a very limited case situation. Most driving is done with a foot on one pedal, or the other. My Tesla and my VW both have the ability to toggle between a low regen or high regen driving mode. Amusingly my former Fiat had the blended brakes that he seems to prefer.

@@allentechpt9026 My Tesla and my VW both have the ability to toggle between low, or high regen braking. On my Model S it is on screen in a menu and on my VW, it is on the gear selector. My previous Fiat had blended brakes with minimal regen outside of pressing the brake. Both the Fiat and VW do not have the ability to turn off creep that mimics a gas cars inability to stop moving in gear, so the braking also mimics a gas car. Tesla lets you turn off creep mode because an electric car is not a gas car. 
I see a lot of accidents in beep and creep, but in a Tesla with autopilot the car will radar lock on the car in front and accelerate and decelerate to maintain the distance pretty reliably. The important thing is to continue looking out the front window and keeping hands on the wheel and feet near the pedals and not watching a movie or playing video games instead. I have seen people doing the most completely stupid things in cars in traffic since the 1980‚Äôs long before there were EV‚Äôs. 
I submit that many accidents in EV‚Äôs are caused because they have a 500 horsepower vehicle that accelerates very quickly and are not used to it. That‚Äôs also why tires get used so quickly. My Tesla needed new tires at 60,0000 miles and again 57,000 miles later.
